docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration is examining whether the new health care law can be used to require insurance plans to offer contraceptives and other family planning services to women free of charge.

docs.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Bravo) MILLION DOLLAR LISTING In this Season 4 opener the real estate agents Josh Flagg, above, and Madison Hildebrand are joined by Josh Altman (who replaces Chad Rogers) in their quest to move some of the most magnificent homes in Los Angeles with the economy still in a slump -- never mind their private lives. The trouble begins as Mr. Altman faces off with an angry seller who thinks he knows best how to market his home. In a new episode of ''Selling New York,'' at 9 on HGTV, the sisters and brokers Samantha Kleier Forbes and Sabrina Kleier Morgenstern have a chance at a double commission when a wealthy bachelor hires them to find his dream home on a budget to match. At 9:30 Ms. Forbes helps her best friend decide whether to stay in the city or move to the suburbs. And Deborah Lupard tries to convince a client that he should actually live in his newly purchased apartment in the financial district of Manhattan before putting it up for sale.

docs.lead_paragraph: According to the National Weather Service, 100 million people live in the path of the monster snow storm that has turned my driveway into a sheet of ice. (I am thinking of teaching the poor, confused dog to do an axel.)

docs.lead_paragraph: Four in five Internet users have searched the Web for health care information, most often checking on specific diseases and treatments, a Pew Internet Project survey reported on Tuesday.

headline.main: Health Care Is High Among Web Searches

docs.abstract: The latest Pew study shows many people are trying to learn about medical diseases that involve pain.
docs.snippet: The latest Pew study shows many people are trying to learn about medical diseases that involve pain.

docs.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (National Geographic) HARD TIME A new season begins with ''The Hustle,'' which explores the underground prison economy -- an illegal system of barter and trade -- inside the Ross Correctional Institution in Chillicothe, Ohio. There, inmates have concocted a variety of money-making strategies to buy items like potato chips and brand-name shampoo at the commissary. Some work as tailors or tattoo artists to earn extra money; others act as lawyers for fellow inmates. (Above, David Applegate, an inmate, displays his tattoos.) The currency of choice: instant coffee. ''Prison City,'' a second episode at 10, interviews inmates at Ross who are using their sentences to prepare for life on the outside. Then there is David Stonestreet, who was sentenced as a teenager to 20 years to life for complicity to aggravated murder. Mr. Stonestreet, who has no hope of parole, has acknowledged his homosexuality and transformed into an alter ego, Twiggy. 8 P.M. (13) PIONEERS OF TELEVISION From ''Dragnet'' and ''The Untouchables'' to ''Mannix'' and ''Mission: Impossible,'' this episode plumbs the underworlds of crime dramas and some of the groundbreakers behind them. The list includes Jack Webb, Desi Arnaz, Bruce Geller, Bill Cosby, Angie Dickinson, Stefanie Powers (above, in ''The Girl From U.N.C.L.E.''), Barbara Bain, Martin Landau, James Garner and Peter Falk.
